Improper waste disposal in Pampanga can have several negative consequences, including:

1. Environmental pollution - Improper disposal of waste, particularly plastics and other non-biodegradable materials, can cause environmental pollution and harm to wildlife, water sources, and air quality.

2. Public health risks - Poor waste management practices can create health risks such as the spread of diseases, infections, and other health hazards.

3. Flooding and other natural disasters - Improperly disposed waste can block drainage systems and exacerbate flooding during heavy rains. It can also contribute to landslides and other natural disasters.

To mitigate the consequences of improper waste disposal in Pampanga, the following measures can be taken:

1. Implementation of effective waste management policies and programs that focus on proper segregation, collection, and disposal.

2. Encouraging the public to adopt sustainable waste management practices through education and awareness campaigns.

3. Investment in new technologies and practices such as composting, recycling, and waste-to-energy projects.

4. Strict enforcement of environmental laws and regulations to ensure compliance with waste management standards and penalties for violators.

5. Collaboration between local government units, civil society organizations, and stakeholders to develop and implement sustainable waste practices in Pampanga.
